objectives: Understand what pronouns are and why we use them.
Learn to use different types of pronouns like 'I', 'you', 'he', 'she', 'it', 'we', 'they'.
Practice replacing nouns with the correct pronouns in sentences.

sections.text: A pronoun is a small word that takes the place of a noun. We use pronouns so we don't have to repeat the same noun again and again in our sentences. This makes our sentences sound better and more natural.

examples.label: Without Pronoun
examples.value: **Ram** is a farmer. **Ram** works in the field.

examples.label: With Pronoun
examples.value: **Ram** is a farmer. **He** works in the field.

examples.label: Without Pronoun
examples.value: **Sita** is a student. **Sita** reads a book.

examples.label: With Pronoun
examples.value: **Sita** is a student. **She** reads a book.

usage_examples: My **mother** cooks food. **She** is very kind.
**Rahul and I** went to the market. **We** bought vegetables.
My **father** is strong. **He** works in the field.

subtopics.title: 2.1. Subject Pronouns: Who Does the Action?

sections.text: Subject pronouns tell us who or what is doing the action in a sentence. They usually come at the beginning of the sentence or before the action word (verb).

examples.label: I
examples.value: used for yourself. Example: **I** am a student.

examples.label: You
examples.value: used for the person you are talking to. Example: **You** are my friend.

examples.label: He
examples.value: used for one boy or man. Example: **He** is a farmer.

examples.label: She
examples.value: used for one girl or woman. Example: **She** is my teacher.

examples.label: It
examples.value: used for one animal or one thing. Example: **It** is a book. (The cow gives milk. **It** is black.)

examples.label: We
examples.value: used for yourself and others. Example: **We** play together.

examples.label: They
examples.value: used for many people, animals, or things. Example: **They** are my classmates. (The birds are flying. **They** are high.)

usage_examples: **He** goes to the market every morning.
**She** helps her mother in the kitchen.
The school bell rang. **It** was time for lunch.
The farmers are happy. **They** had a good harvest.
My sister and I are going. **We** are excited.
The students are studying. **They** want to pass the exam.

subtopics.title: 2.2. Object Pronouns: Who Receives the Action?

sections.text: Object pronouns tell us who or what receives the action of the verb or comes after a preposition (like 'to', 'for', 'with'). They usually come after the action word (verb).

examples.label: Me
examples.value: Example: Give the book to **me**.

examples.label: You
examples.value: Example: I will help **you**.

examples.label: Him
examples.value: Example: Tell **him** to come here.

examples.label: Her
examples.value: Example: We saw **her** at the fair.

examples.label: It
examples.value: Example: I picked **it** up. (referring to a fallen fruit)

examples.label: Us
examples.value: Example: The teacher called **us**.

examples.label: Them
examples.value: Example: I played with **them**.

usage_examples: The teacher will teach **you** a new lesson.
I saw Ram. I talked to **him**.
Can you help **him** carry the water?

sections.text: Possessive pronouns tell us who owns something or to whom something belongs. They show 'possession'. Note: These are often called possessive adjectives because they come before a noun.

examples.label: My
examples.value: Belonging to me. Example: This is **my** book.

examples.label: Your
examples.value: Belonging to you. Example: Is this **your** pencil?

examples.label: His
examples.value: Belonging to him (a boy/man). Example: That is **his** bag.

examples.label: Her
examples.value: Belonging to her (a girl/woman). Example: **Her** sari is new.

examples.label: Its
examples.value: Belonging to it (an animal/thing). Example: The dog wagged **its** tail.

examples.label: Our
examples.value: Belonging to us. Example: This is **our** village.

examples.label: Their
examples.value: Belonging to them. Example: **Their** house is big.

usage_examples: The bird built **its** nest on the tree.
Please give **your** notebook to the teacher.
The cow gives **its** milk to us.

subtopics.title: 4.1. Reflexive Pronouns: Action Back to the Subject

sections.text: Reflexive pronouns are used when the subject and the object of a sentence are the same person or thing. The action 'reflects' back on the doer. They end in '-self' (for one person/thing) or '-selves' (for many).

examples.label: Myself
examples.value: I saw **myself** in the mirror.

examples.label: Himself
examples.value: He taught **himself** to read.

examples.label: Herself
examples.value: She hurt **herself** while playing.

examples.label: Themselves
examples.value: The children cleaned the room **themselves**.

sections.text: Intensive pronouns look exactly the same as reflexive pronouns, but their job is to add emphasis to the subject. They show that the subject did the action personally. If you remove an intensive pronoun, the sentence still makes sense.

examples.label: Myself for emphasis
examples.value: I **myself** saw the farmer plow the field. (Meaning: I saw it with my own eyes.)

examples.label: Herself for emphasis
examples.value: The teacher **herself** told us the story. (Meaning: Not someone else, but the teacher.)

examples.label: Themselves for emphasis
examples.value: The students **themselves** decorated the classroom.

usage_examples: The village headman **himself** came to the meeting.
I will go to the market **myself**.

subtopics.title: 5.1. Pointing to Things Near and Far

sections.text: Demonstrative pronouns are used to point to specific things or people. They tell us if something is near or far, and if it is singular (one) or plural (more than one).

examples.label: This
examples.value: Used for one thing that is near. Example: **This** is my pen.

examples.label: That
examples.value: Used for one thing that is far. Example: **That** is my house (pointing far away).

examples.label: These
examples.value: Used for many things that are near. Example: **These** are my books.

examples.label: Those
examples.value: Used for many things that are far. Example: **Those** are our cows (pointing to cows in a distant field).

usage_examples: **These** are fresh vegetables from our farm.
Can you see **those** mountains in the distance?

sections.text: Interrogative pronouns are used to ask questions. They stand for the thing or person that the question is about.

examples.label: Who
examples.value: Used to ask about a person. Example: **Who** is your teacher?

examples.label: Whom
examples.value: Used to ask about a person (as an object). Example: **Whom** did you see?

examples.label: What
examples.value: Used to ask about a thing or action. Example: **What** is in your bag?

examples.label: Which
examples.value: Used to ask about a choice. Example: **Which** is your house?

examples.label: Whose
examples.value: Used to ask about ownership. Example: **Whose** book is this?

usage_examples: **Who** is coming to the village fair?
**What** did the farmer grow in his field?
**Whom** should I give this letter to?

sections.text: Relative pronouns connect a clause (a part of a sentence) to a noun. They introduce extra information about that noun. The most common ones are who, whom, whose, which, and that.

examples.label: Who (for people)
examples.value: The farmer **who** works hard is successful.

examples.label: Which (for things/animals)
examples.value: The cow **which** is black gives a lot of milk.

examples.label: That (for people or things)
examples.value: This is the book **that** I lost.

examples.label: Whose (for possession)
examples.value: He is the boy **whose** father is the village headman.

usage_examples: I met the man **who** lives next door.
This is the school **that** my father built.
The dog, **which** was barking, is friendly.
I know the girl **whose** mother is a teacher.
The stories **that** my grandmother tells are very interesting.

subtopics.title: 8.1. Referring to General People or Things

sections.text: Indefinite pronouns do not refer to any specific person, thing, or amount. They are vague and 'indefinite'.

examples.label: Referring to People
examples.value: anyone, everyone, someone, nobody, somebody

examples.label: Referring to Things
examples.value: anything, everything, something, nothing

examples.label: Example Sentence 1
examples.value: **Everyone** is present today.

examples.label: Example Sentence 2
examples.value: I want to eat **something**.

examples.label: Example Sentence 3
examples.value: **Nobody** was in the classroom.

usage_examples: **Everybody** in the village helped to clean the well.

sections.text: Reciprocal pronouns express a mutual relationship or action. We use them when two or more people do the same thing to each other.

examples.label: Each other (usually for two people)
examples.value: The two brothers help **each other**.

examples.label: One another (usually for more than two people)
examples.value: The villagers greet **one another** during the festival.

usage_examples: My friend and I share our books with **each other**.
The players in the team support **one another** during the match.
